title: Flames game is last chance for Winnipeg Jets hopefuls to state their cases
text:
Report an error 
CALGARY – Welcome to The Last Chance Cafe, where admittance can be viewed as both a blessing and a curse. 
The Winnipeg Jets have finally arrived at the final game of the pre-season and there are still several jobs left to be won – or lost. 
When the Jets (2-2-2) hit the ice at Scotiabank Saddledome for a return engagement against the Calgary Flames (4-3), several players will be taking one last shot at showing Paul Maurice and company that they belong. 
While the competition remains open, Saturday's results will only be part of the evaluation process. 
This isn't a winner-takes-all situation where the successful parties get to suit up on Thursday against the Boston Bruins in the Jets regular season opener. 
“That would almost be too extreme to say,” Maurice told reporters on Friday morning. “I've got the lineup pretty close in my head for what it's going to look like in Boston. We're still trying to find places that people fit and things that they can do. We're still going to have to make a decision on someone. 
“All of these guys have played well, they're just reinforcing what they've done. We're looking for one more of those games.” 
With 26 players left in camp, the Jets need to trim three bodies, unless someone goes on injured reserve – which remains a possibility when you consider that both Paul Postma (ankle) and Adam Pardy (shoulder) are coming off injuries that required further rehab during the off-season. 
Given the way he's played during the pre-season, it would be a surprise to see defenceman Jay Harrison moved or be placed on waivers. 
Up front, barring an unexpected move, Nikolaj Ehlers and Andrew Copp look like locks at forward. 
Ehlers might even find himself getting a longer look on a line with Mark Scheifele, while Copp is going to be the fourth-line centre. 
That leaves Nic Petan, JC Lipon and Thomas Raffl vying for one spot. 
Given how well he's played, Petan looks like the front-runner to win the job. 
With Andrew Ladd and Adam Lowry expected to sit out the pre-season finale with what Maurice called minor ailments (“not even injuries, they were stiff when they came in”), Petan looks to be getting a shot at playing on a line with Bryan Little and Blake Wheeler. 
Petan has looked comfortable on both the fourth line and in more offensive situations, as his hockey IQ and talent has been on full display. 
When a player has as strong a camp as Petan has, it must be difficult to wonder what else he has to do to win a spot. 
He's done everything that's been asked of him so far, but there's a chance even that might not be enough. 
However, Petan has done an excellent job of staying in the moment and not worrying about how things are going to shake out, with NHL rosters due on Tuesday at 4 p.m. CT. 
“Yeah, you get anxious for sure,” said Petan. “But in those moments, family and friends and guys around the room, they help. You've just got to stay calm.” 
As well as he's played, Lipon is the most likely player to be sent down, but he's taken a big step forward and shown that he's not far away from being a guy Maurice won't be afraid to call on if he needs a fourth-line energy guy. 
Raffl has been one of the most interesting stories to follow during training camp and Saturday's game might be most important of all for him. 
First and foremost, Raffl would love to earn a contract from the Jets. 
But if he can't do that, might there be another NHL team interested in his services or would he consider starting in the AHL, given how close he's come to making the team? 
If neither one of those scenarios transpires, Raffl will head back to Austria. 
No matter how the final decision plays out, it's important for the players on the bubble that this isn't the end of the road, it's actually the starting line. 
And things can change quickly. 
Look no further than the fall of 2011 for a cautionary tale, as Patrice Cormier looked like he had done enough to survive the final cut down to 23 players, only to see the Jets claim winger Brett McLean off waivers. 
The corresponding move saw Cormier return to the minors and while he's received several recalls since that time, he's still not an NHL regular. 
The real work is just beginning.
